Award.AwardTitle: Fractional Imputation for Incomplete Data Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Incomplete data frequently are encountered in survey data due to nonresponse, inaccurate measurement, and two-phase sampling, among other things. Any form of incomplete data can damage the representativeness of a sample, and a naive analysis with incomplete data can lead to biased estimation. Imputation is a process of assigning values to the missing items with the objective of reducing bias and improving the efficiency of the resulting estimators. This project will develop fractional imputation methods as a tool for handling incomplete data for general-purpose estimation. These methods will serve as important building blocks for the establishment of a complete statistical package for analysis of incomplete data that ultimately can be applied to problems in a variety of disciplines, including the social, behavioral, and economic sciences. In particular, the project will develop fractional imputation to address several important problems with incomplete data, including (1) likelihood-based inference, (2) robust estimation using fractional hot deck imputation, (3) synthetic imputation for survey integration, and (4) statistical matching technique.

Because fractional imputation is a relatively new approach for handling incomplete data, there is a critical need for theoretical and methodological development. The advantages of the fractional imputation approach lie in its computational simplicity, wide applicability, and its statistical validity. By using fractional weights, fractional imputation avoids the burden of iterative computation, such as Markov Chain Monte Carlo, for the evaluation of conditional expectation associated with missing data. The proposed approach can be used to estimate parameters consistently and efficiently. The fractional imputation approach can be applied to nonstandard situations such as measurement error models, regression analysis combining two different surveys, and causal inference from observational studies. The impact of the proposed research is therefore substantial because the proposed approach can be used as a general methodology for incomplete data. Because of the computational simplicity and statistical validity of the fractional imputation approach, the results of the proposed research should have wide applicability. It also should have a major impact in providing complete data sets for analysis and new data products combining information from different surveys.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Handling missing data properly is a hot area of research in statistics. Fractional imputation is a tool for handling missing data, specially in survey sampling, and it can be an alternative to multiple imputation, which is a popular method used so far. During the period of 09/01/2016 - 08/31/2017, the PI continues to develop methodology for fractional imputation and has worked with Jongho Im to develop a R package for fractional imputation, called FHDI. The FHDI is released to the public and several presentations were made on this package. Also, the PI has worked with SAS to develop a SAS procedure, called proc Surveyimpute, which implement a version of fractional imputation.

 

Here are the papers published during this period: 

  1. Z. Wang, J.K. Kim, and S. Yang. (2017). ``An approximate Bayesian inference under informative sampling,'' Biometrika, Accepted.
  2. S. Park, J.K. Kim, and D. Stukel (2017). "A measurement error model for survey data integration: combining information from two surveys", Metron, 75, 345-357.
  3. S. Park and J.K. Kim (2017). "Analysis of inaccurate data using mixture measurement error models", Journal of the Korean Statistical Society, Accepted for publication.
  4. K. Morikawa, J.K. Kim, and Y. Kano. (2017). ``Semiparametric maximum likelihood estimation under nonignorable nonresponse,'' Canadian Journal of Statistics, 45, 393-409.
  5. J.K. Kim, S. Park, and Y. Lee (2017). ``Statistical inference using generalized linear mixed models under informative cluster sampling,'' Canadian Journal of Statistics, 45, 479-497.
  6. S. Chen and J.K. Kim (2017). Semiparametric fractional imputation using empirical likelihood in survey sampling, Statistical Theory and Related Fields, 1, 69-81.
  7. Y. Kwon, J.K. Kim, M.C. Paik, and H. Kim (2017). A robust calibration-assisted method for linear mixed effects model under cluster-specific nonignorable missingness. Statistica Sinica, Accepted for publication.
  8. J. Im, E. Ahn, N. Beck, J.K. Kim, and T. Park (2017). Correlation estimation with singly truncated bivariate data. Statistical Method in Medical Research, 36, 1977–1988
  9. Y. Xu, J.K. Kim, and Y. Li. (2017). ``Semiparametric estimation for measurement error models with validation data'', Canadian Journal of Statistics 45, 185–201.
  10. D. Da Silva, C. Skinner, and J.K. Kim. (2017). ``Using Binary Paradata to Correct for Measurement Error in Survey Data Analysis.'' Journal of the American Statistical Association, DOI:10.1080/01621459.2015.1130632.
  11. J.K. Kim and S. Yang. (2017). ``A note on multiple imputation under informative sampling'', Biometrika, 104, 221-228.
  12. Yang, S. and J.K. Kim (2017). ``A semiparametric inference to regression analysis with missing covariates in survey data'', Statistica Sinica, 27, 261--285.
  13. E. Berg, J.K. Kim, and C. J. Skinner. (2016). ``Imputation under informative sampling'', Journal of the Survey Statistics and Methodology, 4, 436--462.
  14. S. Yang and J.K. Kim. (2016). ``Fractional imputation in survey sampling: A comparative review'', Statistical Science, 31, 415--432.

Also, the following papers are submitted or under revision: 

 

  1. W. Yu, J.K. Kim, and T. Park. ``Estimation of Area Under the Curve (AUC) under nonignorable verification bias'', Statistica Sinica, Under second review.
  2. Y. Hwang, S. Lu, and J.K. Kim. ``Bottom-up estimation and top-down prediction in multilevel models: Solar Energy Prediction combining information from multiple sources'', Annals of Applied Statistics, Under second review.
  3. J.K. Kim, S. Park, and K. Kim. ``A note on propensity score weighting method using paradata in survey sampling,'' Survey Methodology, revision invited.
  4. J.K. Kim, Z. Wang, Z. Zhu, and N. Cruze. ``Combining survey and non-survey big data for improved sub-area prediction using a multi-level model'', Journal of Agricultural, Biological, and Environmental Statistics, revision invited.
  5. S. Yang and J.K. Kim. "Predictive mean matching imputation in survey sampling", Biometrika, revision invited.
  6. H. Sang, G. Goh, and J.K. Kim. "Bayesian sparse propensity score estimation for unit nonresponse", submitted to Statistica Sinica.
  7. K. Morikawa and J.K. Kim. "Semiparametric Optimal Estimation under Nonignorable Nonresponse", submitted to Biometrika.
  8. S. Tam and J.K. Kim. "Big data, selection bias, and Ethics - An official statistician's perspective", submitted.
  9. K. Morikawa and J.K. Kim. "A note on the equivalence of two semiparametric estimation methods for nonignorable nonresponse ", submitted to Statistics and Probability Letters.

 



Last Modified: 11/19/2017
Modified by: Jae-Kwang Kim
